sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• (extended-release) use for infections not evaluated; safety beyond 12 weeks of therapy not established
  • IV administration is only recommended when oral therapy is not adequate or tolerated; switch to oral therapy as soon as possible; usual dose, 200 mg IV initially followed by 100 mg IV infused over 60 minutes every 12 hours; MAX 400 mg/24 hours
  • Acne vulgaris: (immediate-release) initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Acne vulgaris: (extended-release capsules) approximately 1 mg/kg ORALLY once daily; 45 to 55 kg, 45 mg ORALLY once daily; 56 to 74 kg, 67.5 mg ORALLY once daily; 75 to 96 kg, 90 mg ORALLY once daily; 97 to 125 kg, 112.5 mg ORALLY once daily; 126 to 136 kg, 135 mg ORALLY once daily; continue treatment for 12 weeks
  • Acne vulgaris: (extended-release tablets) approximately 1 mg/kg ORALLY once daily; 45 to 49 kg, 45 mg ORALLY once daily; 50 to 59 kg, 55 mg ORALLY once daily; 60 to 71 kg, 65 mg ORALLY once daily; 72 to 84 kg, 80 mg ORALLY once daily; 85 to 96 kg, 90 mg ORALLY once daily; 97 to 110 kg, 105 mg ORALLY once daily; 111 to 125 kg, 115 mg ORALLY once daily; 126 to 136 kg, 135 mg ORALLY once daily; continue treatment for 12 weeks
  • Allergy to penicillin - Bacterial infectious disease: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Amebic dysentery; Adjunct: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Anthrax, When penicillin contraindicated: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Bacterial infectious disease: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection, Uncomplicated: 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours for at least 7 days
  • Disease caused by rickettsiae: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Inclusion conjunctivitis: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Infection due to Mycobacterium marinum: 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours for 6 to 8 weeks
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: (methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus or MRSA) 100 mg ORALLY twice daily (guideline dosing)
  • Infection of skin - Soft tissue infection: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, OR 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Meningococcal infectious disease, Asymptomatic carrier state: 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours for 5 days
  • Periodontitis; Adjunct: (subgingival microspheres) individualized dosing; depends on the size, shape, and number of pockets being treated
  • Respiratory tract infection: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily
  • Syphilis: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours for 10 to 15 days, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 10 to 15 days
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum infection, Uncomplicated: 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours for at least 7 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: initial, 200 mg ORALLY followed by 100 mg ORALLY every 12 hours, or 100 mg or 200 mg ORALLY initially, followed by 50 mg ORALLY 4 times daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Not recommended in children younger than 8 years due to potential for tooth discoloration
  • (extended-release) use for infections not evaluated; safety beyond 12 weeks of therapy not established; safety and effectiveness not established in children younger than 12 years
  • IV administration is only recommended when oral therapy is not adequate or tolerated; switch to oral therapy as soon as possible; usual dose, 4 mg/kg IV initially followed by 2 mg/kg IV infused over 60 minutes every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg IV initially followed by MAX 100 mg IV infused over 60 minutes every 12 hours; MAX 400 mg IV in 24 hours
  • Acne vulgaris: (older than 8 years) (immediate-release) 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Acne vulgaris: (12 years or older) (extended-release capsules) approximately 1 mg/kg ORALLY once daily; 45 to 55 kg, 45 mg ORALLY once daily; 56 to 74 kg, 67.5 mg ORALLY once daily; 75 to 96 kg, 90 mg ORALLY once daily; 97 to 125 kg, 112.5 mg ORALLY once daily; 126 to 136 kg, 135 mg ORALLY once daily; continue treatment for 12 weeks
  • Acne vulgaris: (12 years or older) (extended-release tablets) approximately 1 mg/kg ORALLY once daily; 45 to 49 kg, 45 mg ORALLY once daily; 50 to 59 kg, 55 mg ORALLY once daily; 60 to 71 kg, 65 mg ORALLY once daily; 72 to 84 kg, 80 mg ORALLY once daily; 85 to 96 kg, 90 mg ORALLY once daily; 97 to 110 kg, 105 mg ORALLY once daily; 111 to 125 kg, 115 mg ORALLY once daily; 126 to 136 kg, 135 mg ORALLY once daily; continue treatment for 12 weeks
  • Allergy to penicillin - Bacterial infectious disease: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Amebic dysentery; Adjunct: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Anthrax, When penicillin contraindicated: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Bacterial infectious disease: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Disease caused by rickettsiae: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Inclusion conjunctivitis: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Infection due to Mycobacterium marinum: (older than 8 years) 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Infection of skin - Soft tissue infection: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Meningococcal infectious disease, Asymptomatic carrier state: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Respiratory tract infection: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Syphilis: (older than 8 years), 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: (older than 8 years) 4 mg/kg ORALLY initially then 2 mg/kg ORALLY every 12 hours; MAX 200 mg in 24 hours

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment (extended-release): reduce total dose or extend dosing interval
  • renal impairment (suspension, immediate-release tablets/capsules, IV): do not exceed 200 mg in 24 hours
  • geriatric: consider initial doses at low end of dosing range

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Acne vulgaris
  • Allergy to penicillin - Bacterial infectious disease
  • Amebic dysentery; Adjunct
  • Anthrax, When penicillin contraindicated
  • Bacterial infectious disease
  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection, Uncomplicated
  • Disease caused by rickettsiae
  • Inclusion conjunctivitis
  • Infection due to Mycobacterium marinum
  • Infection of skin - Soft tissue infection
  • Meningococcal infectious disease, Asymptomatic carrier state
  • Periodontitis; Adjunct
  • Respiratory tract infection
  • Syphilis
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum infection, Uncomplicated
  • Urinary tract infectious disease
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue
  • Ischemic stroke, Acute
  • Leprosy
  • Rheumatoid arthritis; Adjunct
  • Sclerotherapy

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Hypersensitivity to any tetracycline or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Dermatologic:
  • -- Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome, has occurred, including fatal cases; immediately discontinue if suspected
  • -- Photosensitivity has been reported
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Avoid use during tooth development (eg, last half of pregnancy, infancy, and in children up to age 8), as permanent tooth discoloration and enamel hypoplasia may occur; risk is greater with long-term use
  • -- Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea has occurred in antibiotic use, which has progressed to fatal colitis; discontinuation may be required
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Hepatotoxicity has been reported; use cautiously in patients with hepatic impairment; monitoring recommended
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Autoimmune syndromes, including drug-induced lupus-like syndrome, autoimmune hepatitis, and vasculitis, have been reported with long-term administration; monitoring recommended and immediately discontinue if suspected
  • -- Serious hypersensitivity reactions (eg, anaphylaxis, Stevens Johnson syndrome, erythema multiforme) have been reported
  • -- Serum sickness has been reported; monitoring recommended and immediately discontinue if suspected
  • -- Superinfection may occur; discontinue use if suspected
  • Musculoskeletal:
  • -- Decreases in fibular growth rate were reported in premature infants administered oral tetracycline, which reversed with drug discontinuation
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri) has been reported, with potential for permanent vision loss; discontinue if condition occurs
  • -- CNS effects (eg, lightheadedness, vertigo, dizziness) may occur, which usually resolve rapidly with drug discontinuation
  • Renal:
  • -- Monitoring recommended and dose adjustment may be required in patients with renal impairment, as azotemia, hyperphosphatemia, acidosis, or subsequent liver toxicity may occur with systemic accumulation
  • Reproductive effects:
  • -- Pregnancy should be avoided and use not recommended by either gender of a couple trying to conceive, as drug is a known teratogen
  • Other:
  • -- Injection contains magnesium; cautioned use in patients with heart block or myocardial damage; monitoring recommended in patients with renal impairment
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Avoid concomitant use of penicillin or isotretinoin

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Minocycline: Micromedex: Milk effects are possible.

sub.title: Major
sub.mono:
• Amoxicillin (probable)
  • Ampicillin (probable)
  • Atazanavir (established)
  • Bacampicillin (probable)
  • Bexarotene (theoretical)
  • Cloxacillin (probable)
  • Dicloxacillin (probable)
  • Digoxin (theoretical)
  • Etretinate (theoretical)
  • Isotretinoin (theoretical)
  • Methicillin (probable)
  • Nafcillin (probable)
  • Oxacillin (probable)
  • Penicillin G (probable)
  • Penicillin G Benzathine (probable)
  • Penicillin G Procaine (probable)
  • Penicillin V (probable)
  • Piperacillin (probable)
  • Pivampicillin (probable)
  • Sultamicillin (probable)
  • Temocillin (probable)
  • Tretinoin (theoretical)

sub.title: Moderate
sub.mono:
• Aluminum Carbonate, Basic (probable)
  • Aluminum Hydroxide (probable)
  • Aluminum Phosphate (probable)
  • Calcium (probable)
  • Dihydroxyaluminum Aminoacetate (probable)
  • Dihydroxyaluminum Sodium Carbonate (probable)
  • Iron (probable)
  • Magaldrate (probable)
  • Magnesium Carbonate (probable)
  • Magnesium Hydroxide (probable)
  • Magnesium Oxide (probable)
  • Magnesium Trisilicate (probable)
  • Vitamin A (probable)

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Tooth discolored
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (9%), Headache (23%)
  • Other:Fatigue (9%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme, Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile colitis
  • Hepatic:Hepatic failure, acute, Hepatitis
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Drug hypersensitivity syndrome, Hypersensitivity reaction, Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Neurologic:Bulging fontanelle, Pseudotumor cerebri
  • Other:Serum sickness due to drug

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Minocycline hydrochloride is a semisynthetic derivative of tetracycline. It is primarily bacteriostatic and acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. It has a similar antimicrobial spectrum of activity against a wide range of gram-positive and gram-negative organisms as other tetracyclines

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Oral, extended-release tablets, adults: time to peak, 3.5 to 4 hours
  • Oral, pellet-filled capsule: time to peak, 2.1 hours (range 1 to 4 hours)
  • Effect of food: pellet filled capsule, decreases peak plasma concentration by 11.2% and delays by 1 hour
  • Effect of food: extended-release tablet, no food effects

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Fecal and Renal: one-half to one-third that of other tetracycline
  • Dialyzable: no (hemodialysis), no (peritoneal dialysis)

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• (IV), 11 h to 17 h
  • (Oral), 15.5 h (11.1 h to 22.1 h)
  • Patients with hepatic dysfunction: 11 h to 16 h
  • Patients with renal dysfunction: 18 h to 69 h

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intravenous
    • Reconstitute with 5 mL sterile water for injection and further dilute immediately with 100 to 1000 mL of sodium chloride injection, dextrose injection, or dextrose and sodium chloride injection or with 250 to 1000 mL of LR. Do not dilute with any calcium-containing solutions due to risk of precipitation, which is more likely to occur in neutral and alkaline solutions
    • After dilution into an IV bag, store at room temperature and administer within 4 hours or refrigerate between 2 and 8 degrees C (36 and 46 degrees F) and administer within 24 hours. Avoid rapid administration, infuse over 60 minutes. Prolonged IV administration of minocycline may result in thrombophlebitis.
  • Oral
    • (immediate- or extended-release tablets and capsules) swallow whole; may be taken with or without food; take with adequate amounts of fluids to reduce the risk of esophageal irritation and ulceration
    • (extended-release tablets and capsules) taking with food may reduce risk of esophageal irritation and ulceration
    • (extended-release tablets and capsules) do not chew, crush, or split
    • (suspension) not notably influenced by food or dairy products
  • Subgingival
    • (subgingival microspheres) connect unit-dose cartridge to the handle mechanism by inserting the deformable tip into the spring-loaded cartridge handle
    • (subgingival microspheres) insert unit-dose cartridge to base of periodontal pocket and press thumb ring to expel powder while gradually withdrawing the tip from the base of the pocket
    • (subgingival microspheres) following treatment, avoid interproximal cleaning devices around the treated site for 10 days; avoid chewing hard, crunchy, or sticky foods for 1 week

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Improvement in signs or symptoms of infection indicates efficacy
  • Creatinine BUN in patients with impaired renal function
  • Serum magnesium levels
  • Organ system function, including hematopoietic, renal, and hepatic; periodically
  • Serologic syphilis testing; upon diagnosis of gonorrhea with followup testing 3 months after treatment initiation
  • Clostridium difficile overgrowth; patients reporting diarrhea
  • Ophthalmologic evaluations; in patients reporting visual disturbances
  • Signs of thyroid cancer; with prolonged treatment

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Oral Capsule: 50 MG, 75 MG, 100 MG
    • Oral Tablet: 50 MG, 75 MG, 100 MG
    • Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 45 MG, 90 MG, 135 MG
  • Minocin
    • Intravenous Powder for Solution: 100 MG
    • Oral Capsule: 50 MG, 75 MG, 100 MG
  • Minocin Kit
    Oral Capsule: 50 MG, 100 MG
  • Solodyn
    Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 45 MG, 55 MG, 65 MG, 80 MG, 90 MG, 105 MG, 115 MG, 135 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
TETRACYCLINES
USES: Tetracyclines are used in the treatment of a wide variety of gram-negative and gram-positive infections. PHARMACOLOGY: Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic and exert their antimicrobial effects by inhibition of protein synthesis. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Exposure is relatively common. However, severe toxicity is not observed. Anaphylaxis can develop during therapeutic use in some individuals. OVERDOSE: Severe toxicity following acute overdosage is unlikely. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Nausea and vomiting are common following overdose. SEVERE TOXICITY: Hypersensitivity reactions can develop with therapy in the form of various skin rashes along with more severe reactions including angioedema and anaphylaxis. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Nausea and vomiting with therapeutic use. Epigastric burning and ulceration may also occur. Skin hyperpigmentation may develop. Renal dysfunction, including elevated BUN, may occur due to the antianabolic activity of tetracyclines. DEMECLOCYCLINE: A diabetes insipidus syndrome has been reported following demeclocycline. CHRONIC EFFECTS: Chronic ingestion of therapeutic doses can cause discoloration and enamel defects in the teeth of the fetus if used after the 12th week of pregnancy or in infants during the first 6 to 8 months of life.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
TETRACYCLINES
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Tetracyclines generally have a low order of toxicity. Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. For significant vomiting and/or diarrhea, treat dehydration with IV fluids as necessary. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Monitor renal function following a large overdose. ANAPHYLAXIS: Mild to moderate allergic reactions may be treated with antihistamines with or without inhaled beta adrenergic agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. Diphenhydramine: ADULT: 50 mg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 25 to 50 mg orally every 4 to 6 hours for 24 to 72 hours. CHILD: 1.25 mg/kg orally, IV, or IM initially, then 5 mg/kg/day orally in 4 divided doses for 24 to 72 hours. Treatment of severe anaphylaxis also includes oxygen supplementation, aggressive airway management, epinephrine, ECG monitoring, and IV fluids.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Severe toxicity is unlikely, gastrointestinal decontamination is generally NOT required. DILUTION: Tetracycline and doxycycline have been implicated in causing esophageal ulcerations when taken therapeutically with minimal amounts of fluids. Immediately dilute with 4 to 8 ounces (120 to 240 mL) of water or milk (not to exceed 4 ounces or 120 mL in a child). HOSPITAL: Tetracyclines are generally of a low order of toxicity. In most cases, gastrointestinal decontamination will not be required. Antacids may be useful in managing gastric irritation.
  • Airway management: Airway support is unlikely to be necessary following mild to moderate exposure; airway management may be necessary in patients that develop severe anaphylaxis.
  • Antidote: None.
  • Monitoring of patient: No specific lab work (CBC, electrolyte, urinalysis) is needed unless otherwise clinically indicated following a minor exposure. Monitor renal function after very large ingestions or in patients with baseline impaired renal function. Plasma tetracycline concentrations are not clinically useful.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis and hemoperfusion are unlikely to be of value with these agents because of their high degree of protein binding. Tetracycline is not dialyzable.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: An asymptomatic child taking an inadvertent 1 to 2 tablets can likely be monitored at home, or an asymptomatic adult taking an inadvertent extra dose can be safely managed at home. Tetracycline and doxycycline have been implicated in causing esophageal ulcerations when taken therapeutically with minimal amounts of fluids. Immediately dilute with 4 to 8 ounces (120 to 240 milliliters) of water or milk (not to exceed 4 ounces or 120 milliliters in a child). OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Patients with a deliberate self-harm ingestion should be evaluated in a healthcare facility and monitored until symptoms resolve. Obtain a baseline CBC and renal function following a significant exposure. Patients may be discharged to home once symptoms have resolved and laboratory studies are within normal limits. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients experiencing severe or persistent anaphylactic symptoms should be admitted for further monitoring and treatment as indicated. CONSULT CRITERIA: Contact a medical toxicologist or Poison Center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear. Patients with a deliberate self-harm ingestion should be evaluated by a mental health specialist.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
TETRACYCLINES
TOXICITY: The minimal toxic or lethal dose is not well established in the literature. Severe toxicity following acute tetracycline overdose is unlikely. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULT: ORAL: Tetracycline: 1 to 2 g/day; Doxycycline: 100 to 200 mg/day (up to 400 mg/day for some indications); Minocycline: 200 mg/day; Demeclocycline: 600 mg/day. PEDIATRIC: Tetracycline (older than 8 years): 25 to 50 mg/kg/day, up to 3 g/day; Demeclocycline: 6.6 to 13.2 mg/kg/day; max 600 mg/day; Doxycycline (older than 8 years): 4 to 8 mg/kg/day, usually up to 200 mg/day (up to 400 mg/day for some indications); Minocycline (older than 8 years): 4 mg/kg initial dose, then 2 mg/kg every 12 hours.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid driving or using hazardous machines until drug effects are realized due to dizziness, vertigo, and lightheadedness.
  • Warn male and female patients to avoid pregnancy. Additional form of birth control recommended due to potential for decreased effectiveness of oral contraceptives.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of pseudotumor cerebri or severe skin reactions (ie, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, erythema multiforme, DRESS syndrome).
  • Oral: Side effects may include fatigue, headache, dizziness, vertigo, pruritus, or hyperpigmentation (ie, skin, oral cavity).
  • Subgingival: Side effects may include local sensitivity, dental pain, or stomatitis.
  • Advise patient to avoid excessive exposure to natural or artificial sunlight due to photosensitivity.
  • Counsel patient to report symptoms of Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea or hepatotoxicity (ie, hepatitis).
  • Tell patient to report symptoms of an autoimmune syndrome (ie, lupus-like syndrome, hepatitis, vasculitis, serum sickness).
